p.seg: SEVENTEENTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF THE STATE BANKING BOARD SHOWING THE CONDITION OF THE Building and Loan Associations OF NEBRASKA FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30. 1909 SUBMITTED TO THE GOVERNOR AND THE STATE BANKING BOARD SEPTEMBER 1. 1909 BY E. ROYSE, SECRETARY 1909

DEPARTMENT OF HANK! NO OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA BOARD HON. SILAS R. BARTON Auditor of Public Accounts and President HON. L. G. BRIAN State Treasurer HON. W. T. THOMPSON Attorney General E. ROYSE Secretary V R. PERSINGER Chief Clerk MAUDE HOGE Clerk EXAMINERS E. E. EMMETT C. W. EBWIN C. H. BEAUMONT E. 8. MICKEY

State of Nebraska, Department of Banking, Lincoln, September 1, 1909. B Excellency, Ashton C. Shallenberger, Governor of Ne - iska, and the Honorables Silas R. Barton, L. Q. Brian and T. Thompson, the State Banking Board of the State of braska : Gentlemen: — In compliance with Section 3a of Chapter 8 of the Compiled Statutes of the State of Nebraska for 1903, re - quiring the Secretary of the State Banking Board to make to the Governor and State Banking Board annual reports, I have the honor to submit herewith the seventeenth annual report of the Department of Banking for the period beginning July 1, 1908, and ending June 30, 1909, showing the condition of the building and loan associations of the State of Nebraska at the close of business June 30, 1909, compiled from annual reports of the several building and loan associations submitted to the State Banking Board, in accordance with the provisions of the building and loan act, approved April 4, 1899. Tabulated state - ments, detailed reports, and such information and comments touching this report as are deemed beneficial will be found on the following pages. Very respectfully, E. ROYSE Secretary State Banking Board.
Associations for the years from 1892, the first year reports wer« received, to 1909, inclusive, showing the totals of all Building and Loan Associations in the State for the years above stated.

SECRETARY OF THE STATE BANKING BOARD 49 Seventy Associations were in active operation and sul> mitted reports to this Department at the close of business June 30, 1909, an- increase of two over the number reporting last Etake pleasure in calling your attention to the dat;t g the building and loan associations under your super - contained in this report, and especially to the statement preceding page showing the increases and decreases the year. Ee exceptionally strong condition shown is certainly ing. The increase of nearly four million dollars in luring the last year demonstrates not only the activity of these associations in the financial field, but shows conclu - sively that the people of the state appreciate and are taking advantage of the opportunities they offer. They occupy a place in the financial structure of the state peculiar to them - selves and differing materially from all other financial or - ganizations contemplated by law. As the earned increment of the state increases in volume and the small saver and home builder increases, the field of building and loan associations widens and their usefulness becomes more apparent. I feel safe in predicting that in the years to come the foundations upon which these associations have been built in the beginning will be found to have been laid with great wisdom. No other state has used greater pre - caution for the protection of borrower and stockholder, and I believe no other state has a law which adheres more tena - ciously to the theory of mutuality, which is an ultimate corner stone of all building and loan associations. There has not been a building and loan failure in the state since the present law went into effect in 1899, and there are no "get-rich-quick" Home Co-operative installment in - vestment companies licensed to do business in the state. Very respectfully, E. ROYSE,
